39341831.review:
Достойное продолжение первой части. Как говорится в самой игре - игроки получили именно то, чего ожидали после прохождения первой истории.

Могу лишь добавить, что эта история, несмотря ни на что, воспринимается несколько иначе, чем предыдущая. Это связано не только с тем, что нам известны определённые сюжетные моменты и у нас из-за этого возникли конкретные ожидания. Дело в том, что данная история несёт в себе совершенно другие эмоции и потомусоздаёт другую атмосферу. Если вы настроились на конкретный лад после Оникакуши, то Ватанагаши будет умело подавлять это. И даже когда наступит определённый момент, когда вы подумаете "Я знал это с самого начала", у вас не будет этого триумфального тона, упрекающего историю в предсказуемости. Поверьте, тут всё выполнено великолепно. Создатели хорошо поработали.

Не вдаюсь детали, чтобы избежать спойлеров.

Как и с прошлой частью, рекомендую дополнительную установку озвучки для создания атмосферности.
Хотя теперь с озвучкой какая-то лажа и иногда реплики произносятся не теми персонажами, какими должны быть. Я даже сначала подумал, что это ошибка перевода (играю на английском). Но всё встало на свои места, когда я услышал как всё должно было быть. Не знаю как так получилось. Просто актёры озвучки местами спутали реплики. И это странно.

39216423.review:
Compared to Onikakushi I found this arc slightly more vicious than the VN has procclaimed. It had more twisted psychology, violence, creepiness and mysteries surrounding than the first chapter. This chapter is also included in the anime second season I believe but it was my first time reading it.  Ofcourse regardless of saying that let me state that seriously considering the amount some people must have paid to get this VN they should have provided some good BG and voices! I think it was really unfair for the developers to devoid the PC users of that priviledge >.> Anyways the pro is you could install the PS3 graphics and voice patch to get the full required benefits. And with those two elements this visual novel is super duper great. As usual the story is bone chilling and still shocked and gave me goosebumps- it felt so nice to get into the higurashi series again such a blessing. 

In this arc the main focused character would be Mion and as the other chapter verified in the All Cast Review it also focuses on the history of the demon village a bit more closely. Being in a country where the civilians are considered to be half demons well I too know that feeling. Because we are decended to be from snakes, demons and angels (LOL). The most important point is in Asian culture superstitions has a great emphasis and since collectivism still thrives around the corner many communities get bullied but the victims never rebel. Also the VN focuses a bit more on Japanese war crimes, according to my small research there were many incidents of Japanese cannibalism against US soldiers where they were consumed with a mixture of hatred and also because of the desperate need of food. The nation responsible denies them ofcourse but since it's war anything can happen. So likewise you'd learn a great deal of history from this VN especially about Japan. 

The characters are still great- my all lovable and cute rena-san is still the best.Despite being a girl myself I'm such a fan of her. In the VN you would encounter many moments where the protagonist is threatened  but then you would also see how the side characters handle the exteme situations. Those are actually things that should be learn- keeping a cool head would make you see things clearler and being panicked would get you down more into a pinch. New characters were introduced into this arc to develop the story but it was kinda boring at first in every visual novel of higurashi because of the over exaggerated club games. And the same scenario keeps repeating: the watanagashi, oyashiro sama, demoned away and deaths etc. 

Despite the great story- the music was still unsuited for the VN at this type of development. It should be more refined. And without hesitation I did use the graphic and voice patch so it was a bit bearable. Also keep in mind that some lines won't be voiced by the characters and also I had to save my game numerously since it crashed a little bit at the early scenarios of the novel but it stopped happening in the end (my guess is you should stop chatting with friends and stop unnecessary background programs from running- but this seems illogical but idk) The story is greatly atmospheric and you totally feel like you are the main protagonist regardless of the gender. His pain is your pain and his frustrations are your frustrations. 

Well with all that said- still don't underestimate this VN you totally don't know what you're getting yourself into especially if you are not acquainted with the higurashi series at all, please prepare yourself. Sometimes even logic goes beyond reasoning at some point. So keep your wits about you ;)

38864617.review:
全成就+1。

+劇情有意思
+壞掉

-沒中文

基本上看過動畫，遊戲沒中文就懶了。
趁著HB出組包入手收藏。
做為龍騎士07的成名作，純視覺小說沒有選項。
作為推理故事但是沒有解答的設計很有趣。
1~4章是為出題篇，在不同的時間軸上去分析內幕。
第5章後才是解答篇，也是在不同的時間軸。

遊戲設定上可以改成看角色原始模樣，很有趣。
在詳細上遊戲應該比動畫要好。
不過這部要看獵奇，要看顏藝跟壞掉，還是要看動畫或漫畫阿。

壞掉好棒啊~~

38816136.review:
Z góry zaznaczam, że oceniam "Watanagashi" w kontekście całości, stad łapka w górę. Gdybym nie brała pod uwagę tego, że to część cyklu, to stanowczo bym jej nie polecała.

Zacznijmy zatem od pozytywów: jest to druga część "Higurashi", która przedstawia alternatywną historię (ale czy na pewno?) wydarzeń znanych z jedynki. Punktem wyjścia a zarazem osią całej opowieści jest tu (genialna moim zdaniem) postać Mion, do której to tym razem, zamiast do Reny, zbliża się Keiichi. Dowiadujemy się więcej o niej, o jej rodzinie i roli, jaką miała w tragicznych wydarzeniach w wiosce. Rena tym razem schodzi na nieco dalszy plan, za to więcej głębii zyskują Rika i Satoko, czego mi brakowało w "Onikakushi", także uważam to za duży plus. Jednym z ciekawszych rozwiązań fabularnych jest tu przedstawienie niejako "lustrzanego odbicia" osobowości czy decyzji niektórych postaci z poprzedniej części - przykładowo, w jedynce [spoiler]Keiichi bardzo ufa Oishiemu, tutaj wręcz go nie cierpi, dzięki czemu historia prezentuje się mocno inaczej[/spoiler]. Dodaje to nieco innej perspektywy do całości, dzięki czemu można weryfikować swoje teorie na temat o co tu właściwie chodzi :). 

No właśnie, ale lustrzane odbicie nadal jest odbiciem i niestety powtarzalność motywów bardzo, bardzo nudzi. "Watanagashi" jest nieco dłuższa od "Onikakushi", ale tam przynajmniej napięcie budowane było stopniowo, aż w końcówce nie można było się oderwać od czytania. Tutaj na piętnaście godzin lektury mniej więcej godzina była punktem kulminacyjnym - bardzo dobrym i niespodziewanym, przyznaję - ale to stanowczo za krótko w porównaniu z ciągnącymi się w nieskończoność opisami lekcji czy gier naszej ekipy. Może to wina tego, że pod względem gatunkowym dwójce bliżej do thrillera niż horroru, ale moim zdaniem nie jest to wytłumaczenie.

Sama się zastanawiam, czy w przypadku "Watanagashi" nie lepiej sięgnąć po mangę czy anime, a czytanie sobie zwyczajnie odpuścić. Myślę, że dostarczy ona czytelnikowi takich samych wniosków czy wiedzy, a dzięki temu można sobie oszczędzić nudy.

38775805.review:
Очень плохо что ни задний фон, ни визуализированниые персонажи не тем более музыка не влияют на атмосферу в обще.  Поиграв минут 8-20 понимаешь что 95 % атмосферы составляет лишь текст. В итоге получается этакий дисбаланс, когда текст впереди, а остальное еще на старте. Что я считаю новелле такое непростительно. Так все выше перечисленные минусы новеллы сильно ставят под сомнение ее покупку.

Превосходно в этой новелле только одно из-за чего мигом забываешь все минусы и это [b] сюжет [/b]. Он прост и одновременно гениален. Диалоги и персонажи на высоте. Радует то что персонажи всегда мыслят только из ходя своего характера, не состыковок в тексте мало. Юмор разнообразен. Из особых плюсов (для меня лично.) то что здесь настолько умело нагнетается атмосфера страха, настолько же разряжается напряженная обстановка. И в плане как детектива не огорчили, разгадка тайны все время у нас была перед носом, но нам тайны раскроют намного позже, в других главах.

И поэтому я считаю что несмотря на все недостатки лучше новеллы которая качественно объединяет в себе и мистику и драму и хорор и детектив (хоть он здесь и слабенький) вам не найти.

Итог: юмор 9/12, Музыка 3/12, Сюжет(диалоги) 12/12, Концовка 11/12.

38660084.review:
想念那一个个消逝的夏天，想念那耀眼的阳光、温暖的风，以及...那一次次清脆悠曳的蝉鸣。
或多或少的牵挂，或悲或喜的命运，好似树上形状各异的叶；有些色泽鲜艳，有些枯黄暗淡，但却有着一样的经络分明，在树上缀满，在风中摇曳。叶的间隙，掩不住阳光，盖不过蝉鸣，更藏不住一次次熟悉的故事，熟悉的人、朋友...
       寒蝉鸣泣之时，关于追溯真相，还原事实的故事。它还原的不仅仅是死亡的真实样貌，更是还原了人性的本来面目。
　　
　　雏见泽,在这个人口不足2000人的小村子里，每年都会发生一些奇怪的事情。
　　雏见泽村连续怪死事件(1979年～1983年)：每年6月的某日，一定会有1人死亡，1人消失，十分离奇。围绕着巨大水库的争斗死亡的惨案连续发生，隐藏在昭和中期的怪事逐个清晰起来了。
　　这是阴谋，是偶然，还是有什么东西在作祟。
　　应该存在的人消失了，不应该存在的人出现了。
　　昨夜相会的人已经死了，现在活着的人也死了。
　　
　　惨剧不可避免。除了屈服别无他法。
　　但是，不能屈服。
　　只有你才能去面对。
　　
　　夜蝉的鸣声依旧，仿佛宣告着这个早来的夏日。
　　
　　人性，是比死亡更让人恐慌且避之不及的存在。
　　每一篇章，都会有一段极其冷静的陈述。
　　每集片尾，都会有一段预告词在进行着极度迫切的追问。
　　
　　《鬼隐篇》
　　请你不要哭泣。
　　即使世间不能原谅你的罪恶，我也将会宽恕。
　　请你不要哭泣。
　　即使你不能原谅这个世界，我也将会从容。
　　所以 请告诉我。
　　我要怎样做 才能得到你的饶恕。
　　1.
　　能相信吗 亲眼所见的事实
　　能相信吗 所发生的事实
　　能相信吗 我
　　寒蝉鸣泣之时 鬼隐篇 其之二 隐情 你 能相信吗？
　　2.
　　你所能看到的 只是虚伪的居所
　　在那能看到的 只是空虚的眼神
　　我所能看到的 只是重演的悲剧
　　寒蝉鸣泣之时 鬼隐篇 其之三 疑心 你 能相信吗？
　　3.
　　请不要畏惧 明日的彼方
　　请不要伤害 你的心灵
　　请不要道歉 昨日的一切
　　寒蝉鸣泣之时 鬼隐篇 其之四 歪 你 能相信吗？
　　4.
　　希望你能凝视 真正的自我
　　希望你能原谅 无常的你
　　希望你能理解 另一个我
　　寒蝉鸣泣之时 绵流篇 其之一 嫉妒 你 能相信吗？
　　
　　《绵流篇》
　　不能治愈你的饥渴。
　　因为追求真实的你 不能认同。
　　不能治愈你的饥渴。
　　因为你所的追求真实 并不存在。
　　尽管如此 还是渴望着满足你的希望。
　　因为把你扔进沙漠的人 正是我自己。
　　1.
　　想见到的 是黑暗中的形状
　　想听到的 是迟疑的脚步声
　　想知道的 是真正的居所
　　寒蝉鸣泣之时 绵流篇 其之二 鹰野 你 能相信吗？
　　2.
　　正在颤抖的 是你的心灵
　　正在靠近的 是黑暗之影
　　正在冻结的 是虚伪的我
　　寒蝉鸣泣之时 绵流篇 其之三 谎言 你 能相信吗？
　　3.
　　无法终结的 后悔
　　无法致歉的 故事
　　铭刻在那的 是另一个我
　　寒蝉鸣泣之时 绵流篇 其之四 愿望 你 能相信吗？
　　4.
　　已经忘却的是 你的那份温柔
　　不断重复的是 悲伤的脚步声
　　邀你进门的是 记忆的小碎片
　　寒蝉鸣泣之时 崇杀篇 其之一 哥 你 能相信吗？
　　
　　《崇杀篇》
　　井底的青蛙是幸福的。
　　因为它不理会井外的世界。
　　井底的青蛙是幸福的。
　　因为井外的世界与它无关。
　　然而你也是幸福的。
　　因为你对世界一无所知。
　　1.
　　无法全部拯救的 是一行泪水
　　无法完全阻止的 是向绝望的呐喊
　　将来拜访的 是仇恨的连锁
　　寒蝉鸣泣之时 崇杀篇 其之二 羁绊 你 能相信吗？
　　2.
　　所寻求的 是往昔所拥有的安睡
　　所听到的 是充斥着恶意的雨声
　　所流入的 是通向黑暗的门扉
　　寒蝉鸣泣之时 崇杀篇 其之三 分界 你 能相信吗？
　　3.
　　诱惑的是 后悔的脚步声
　　追赶的是 疑惑的脚步声
　　彷徨的是 另一个自己
　　寒蝉鸣泣之时 崇杀篇 其之四 失物 你 能相信吗？
　　5.
　　脚步声 是由过去而来的细语
　　所看见的 是迷雾之中的真实
　　所听到的 是给予你的宽恕
　　寒蝉鸣泣之时 崇杀篇 其之五 谢罪 你 能相信吗？
　　6.
　　来访的，是黄昏的光辉。
　　闯入的，是时光的黑暗。
　　邂逅的，是过去与未来的间隙。
　　寒蝉鸣泣之时 暇溃篇 其之一 雏见泽 你 能相信吗？
　　
　　《暇溃篇》
　　问我谁是真凶？
　　这不正是寻找它的故事吗？
　　问我真凶是谁？
　　知道那是“什么”的真凶吗？
　　谁是凶手？
　　将要杀死我的凶手是谁？
　　1.
　　所追求的 是不变的容貌
　　所寻找的 是阳光的退路
　　被给予的 是如旧的悲伤
　　寒蝉鸣泣之时 暇溃篇 其之二 征兆 你 能相信吗？
　　2.
　　邂逅的 是指向温柔的代价
　　坠落的 是通向悲伤的迷宫
　　焦虑的 是走向憎恨的思绪
　　寒蝉鸣泣之时 明目篇 其之一 初恋 你 能相信吗
　　
　　《目明篇》
　　波珠遗失在沙漠里 少女哭泣着。
　　百年间少女在沙漠里搜寻。
　　或许是海洋而不是沙漠 少女哭泣着。
　　百年里少女在海洋间搜寻。
　　或许是山丘而不是海洋 少女哭泣着。
　　存在或不存在 还要质疑几百年？
　　1.
　　所失去的 是平日的归路
　　无法守护的 是与你的约定
　　无法消去的 是我的回忆
　　寒蝉鸣泣之时 明目篇 其之二 区别 你 能相信吗
　　2.
　　被消去的 是记忆的芬芳
　　所看到的 是仇恨的伤痕
　　所响起的 是过去的足音
　　寒蝉鸣泣之时 明目篇 其之三 鬼之血脉 你 能相信吗
　　3.
　　所追求的 是仅有的安稳
　　所见到的 是仇恨的回廊
　　所堕落的 是黑暗的彼方

《寒蝉鸣泣之时》是日本同人社团07th Expansion制作的同人游戏系列，《寒蝉鸣泣之时 绵流篇》是《寒蝉鸣泣之时》同人系列游戏的第二作，发行于2002年12月30日。《寒蝉鸣泣之时》目前登陆PC,PlayStation 2,PlayStation 3,PlayStation Vita,Nintendo DS,IOS,Android平台，并含有广播剧，电视剧，漫画，小说，动画，真人电影等相关产物。

《寒蝉鸣泣之时》用平行的次元轮回的形式，深刻体现了存在于人们内心深处的罪恶，只有团结一致，才能克服困难，了解一切。游戏没有任何选项，出题篇中通过平行世界的各种角度给出谜题和线索提示，玩家利用线索进行推理，解答篇中玩家才能了解到真正的答案。

《寒蝉鸣泣之时 绵流篇》和《鬼隐篇》在同一时间轴，讲述了前原圭一在游戏大会中将得到的奖品送给了礼奈，后来结识了魅音的孪生姐妹诗音。绵流祭当天，圭一与鹰野、富竹、诗音进入祭具殿。和伙伴告别后，其他人死亡，圭一是唯一一个活下来的人，随着事情的发展，魅音的奇怪举动引起了人们的注意...

It has pretty much same flaws as first game but the story aspect is in my opinion better and i liked it mutch more then first VN.

Finaly my verdict is that Higurashi - Watanagashi is very good, very intense murder-mystery VN and i like it a lot despite the low budged impression.

35265126.review:
Chapter 2 kept to the high standard that chapter 1 set, if not raising the standard altogether.

[b]Please note that this is the second chapter of a series, play through chapter 1 before this,[/b]

[h1]What is it?[/h1]
Higurashi when they cry is a sound novel series. The games use sound effects, images, and appropriate music to generate an atmosphere for the story. This is done much better than the last game (Yse, I know it seems almost impossible) as they have added more music that really helps to get you immersed (Cheesy though this may sound). The key characters have sprites to help you get a better idea of their appearance, and their current mood. Images tend to be scenes so you can get the idea of where the character(s) is(are).

[h1]Story[/h1]
Like the last chapter this game has a brilliant story, however does not directly follow up from the last chapter, it is set over the same few days where a different chain of events occur instead.

The story could be described as an emotional joyride for what kind of emotions your character feels (And that what it wants you too feel too) The character you play expresses himself in a manner of ways of goes through happiness, sorrow, hope, despair, regret, fear, feeling sympathetic towards the culprit, and what is almost love. (Though not in that order)

Your character is still new to hinamizawa, however you have the knowledge of events from past chapters to take a different standpoint on events. After breaking a taboo of the village, people start to go missing, all of which had some connection to the chain of events leading up to your breaing of said taboo. Your character wants to find out what is happening, and, if possible, put a stop to it before anyone else you care about gets hurt.

As said once before the idea of this game is to put you in the character's shoes, throughout the main story you shall see what he sees, hear what he hears, know what he thinks, and (dependant on your immersion) feel what he feels.
The optional tips give you (The player) to learn more about the situation than your character.
[b]NOTE: This game follows a set path, there are no choices to be made.[/b]

[h1]Cost[/h1]
For the experiance, I'd say this game is definately worth the cost (Much like the last game.) The playtime at the time I posted this was around 16.7 hours. So in my books, chapter 2 is worth the cost as much as chapter 1 was.

[h1]After Party[/h1]
After you have completed the game, you unlock the "After Party". This is also titled as the "All cast review session". In it, the characters break down the 4th wall and share their opinions on the game, and their theories behind the inccidents, also discussing what the beta players thought. (A surprisingly nice way to end the game, as it somewhat doubles up as a brief recap.) It also makes some hints at preperations for the third chapter (For which I also have high expectations for.)

This game, as said above, was great. I just fell into the world they were trying to portray, even after seeing the anime, some elements of the game surprised me. (There are differences between the anime and games.)

Why are you still reading this? Haven't you bought this chapter already?

Antes de comenzar con mi opinión personal, debo decir que este capítulo lo he disfrutado con mods que modifican tanto los sprites (de manera opcional, puedes poner los diseños de los personajes de esta nueva versión aunque los fondos si que cambian) como añaden voces a los personajes, cosa que esto último no se incluye en esta versión que hay en Steam y recomiendo fervientemente que lo añadais, ya que esta aventura gana muchísimo con esto. 

Tras ese final que nos dejó a todos bastante sorprendidos en el primer capítulo, regresamos a Hinamizawa desde el punto de vista (una vez más) de Keiichi-kun, pero esta ocasión en vez de centrarse más en Rena puede considerarse la "ruta" de Mion, la joven lider del club en el cual está nuestro protagonista, donde veremos nuevas facetas que no pudimos apreciar en el primer capítulo y demases que no quiero mencionar para no estropear la experiencia a nadie. ¿Está esta historia a un nivel de calidad del primero? Me atrevo a decir que incluso lo supera, nadie podrá negarme eso en la segunda mitad del juego, simplemente BRUTAL: giros argumentales impactantes y momentos que hará que un escalofrio recorra tu cuerpo sin que puedas despegar la mirada de la pantalla. Cabe decir que descubriremos cosas nuevas de los misterios que rodean esta aparente tranquila villa además de conocer mejor al elenco de compañeros de Keiichi (y no solo hablo de Mion) incluyendo algún que otro secundario.

Por lo demás, la banda sonora sigue siendo exquisita como vimos en el primer capítulo, manteniendo los excelente personajes (obviamente) y presentando alguno que otro nuevo. La única pega posible es que no haya doblaje, algo que en una novela de este tipo hace que pierda mucho, ya que el papel inmersivo que ejerce es totalmente necesario pero como dije antes podeis bajaros los mods y no preocuparos por esta carencia.

Hablando de la duración me atrevería a decir que es un poco más corto este capítulo respecto al primero pero no llega a ser corto ni mucho menos, lo que será inevitable es que quieras más que es algo completamente distinto.

¿Recomiendo When They Cry Hou - Ch.2 Watanagashi?
Si disfrutaste del primer capítulo no sé a que esperas a comenzar a leer este, ya que no solo mantiene su calidad sino que mejora, por lo que claramente no puedo parar de recomendarlo y animar a que disfrutes de los terribles secretos que esconde Hinamizawa.

31748896.review:
[b]I will not quench your thirst, for you seek the truth and could not accept that.
I will not quench your thirst, for the truth you desire does not exist.
But I still want to quench your thirst, for I am the one who cast you into the desert. - Frederica Bernkastel[/b]

Well, here comes the second chapter of [i]Higurashi When They Cry[/i] series: [i]Ch.2 - Watanagashi[/i]. It is equally ambiguous in its narrative and mysterious with its story pacing just as the first game, yet this time its revelations hold more of a chilling murder/mystery rather than a supernatural horror compared to the first game. The game is just as good though, feeding into your curiosity furthermore by presenting a storyline that doesn't fit with the timetable of events presented to us in the previous game.

Completing the first game - I detest spoilers, so I'll try to be vague as possible when it comes to plot points - it should be obvious that it is impossible for both games to be part of the same timeline. Even though, the core story elements are more or less the same with the first game - in which you are Keiichi Maebara who has just moved into the silent town of Hinamizawa and befriended a bunch of girls with quirky characters - the dynamic and events themselves in nature completely differ. Sure, we go through a sweet, careless period with girls from Keiichi's perspective; and after the night of the Watanagashi festival everything takes a turn for the creepy and mysterious. But this time we are presented with some kind of a "what if" scenario. This time, Keiichi isn't present during the festival, since he's been busy breaking a taboo alongside Takano Miyo, Tomitake Jiro and a newly introduced character in this arc: [spoiler]Shion Sonozaki, our beloved friend Mion's little sister[/spoiler].

This arc takes a turn to shed some light into the background of all three families leading Hinamizawa - clans Sonozaki, Kimiyoshi and Furude. Alongside many narrative details that we are already familiar with, this new game brings in a closer perspective to Sonozaki clan, [spoiler]and Sonozaki twins themselves respectively[/spoiler]. Being the second question arc in the series, it arises more questions rather than answering old ones, but the game is invaluable for its quality on introducing a thorough history of the village, including both the folklore narrative and actual historical facts, very useful to explain the local psycho-dynamic for the village.

As we've been able to observe in the first game, the narrative pacing heavily relies on sound effects, soundtrack pieces and the timing of them to be introduced with appropriate narrative sequences. Through this formula, a cheery scene may suddenly turn into an uncanny one; and a dramatic moment may suddenly turn into a full throttle horror scene. Everything within the game relies on this element of absurd consequentiality, keeping you on your toes.

It may be important to note that this storyline is a bit more brutal compared to the first one, since we have mostly observed a period of dreadful paranoia, alongside some not very closely examined murder occurrences in [i]Onikakushi[/i]. Here, we'll travel down into the belly of the beast, dealing with more death scenarios, more gore scenes and probably more psychotic monologues than necessary. I sure do love the series but I cannot handle villain monologues well, so there has been moments that I couldn't wait for someone specific to shut up... Oh, well, it ended up being satisfying in its own right anyhow.

Ready? Here it comes then. It's the same pattern: carefree days of youth and friendship, followed by a brutal mystery that ends up with an eerie, eerie trauma. Result? There is a village named Hinamizawa... There, weird and brutal things happen all the time. I am yet to see any kind of good ending in these series. Well, we'll see. 2 games down, 6 to go. Enjoy!

Please also check out Lady Storyteller's Curator page [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/ladystoryteller#curation]here[/url] - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

30523259.review:
Higurashi When They Cry Hou-Ch. 2 Watanagashi is the second chapter in the Higurashi series.  Like the first chapter, this one is a kinetic visual novel so there are no choices to be made-just simply read and enjoy the story.  Despite that this is the second chapter, it doesn't follow the events of the first chapter.  Rather, it kind of restarts the timeline at the beginning of the first chapter but there are alternate events that occur this time, with the focus being more on Mion and the appearance of her twin sister Shion.  Shion didn't make an appearance at all in the first chapter and then, the focus was more on Rena and getting introduced to Hinamizawa and what happens there.  Therefore, you don't really need to have played the previous chapter before playing this one although it does help as a point of reference.  

Basically, this is a horror mystery game where you play as Keiichi Maebara and after the night of Watanagashi (a ceremony that takes place yearly late in June), there is one person found dead and another person who goes missing.  At least, that's what has happened in Hinamizawa for the past four years although when it happens again (this year being the fifth year), something quite different happens although I won't spoil what it is.  There are twists and turns and at the end of this game, there is a surprise twist, just like in ch.1.  If you want to know more details in regards to the story, then buy the game and find out for yourself although perhaps it might be best to wait until after my review has been completely read.  ;)

So now on to my review of Higurashi-Ch.2 Watanagashi.  I truly enjoyed the story and I liked that different events happened this time around and that I got to find out more about Mion, Shion, and their family.  The events up until the night of Watangashi are pretty tame so if you expect to be scared from the get go, that won't be the case.  This is a story where the suspense is built up but I do like that.  It makes for excellent writing, and that isn't easy to find nowadays.  The art (with the updated sprites) is beautiful and the music was varied and appropriate.  Tips are included in between chapters/days that give the reader more insight as to what's going on, as you only get a limited view when you play as Keiichi.  After you finish the game, an Extras feature is unlocked on the main menu and clicking on it gives you access to the tips as well as replay particular chapters/days.  Also, it gives you access to the after party where the characters chat and give their ideas as to what happened.  

Overall, I enjoyed Higurashi-Ch.2 Watangashi and I'm excited to play Higurashi-Ch.3 Tatarigoroshi next and find out how it'll differ from the previous two chapters.  I'd recommend this game for anyone who enjoys reading a good horror, mystery story and likes built-up suspense.  Also, if you don't mind the occasional humor included here and there, then yup, definitely give this game a try.  ^^

But I warn you, this game is almost unforgivably fluffy. You know what I mean by fluffy? I mean it's full of fluff, not a whole lot of hard substance floating around in this one and that deeply saddened me.

The beginning chapters are the absolute worst and as the name of this sequel(?) suggests, nothing of real value since the first game appears until you reach the Watanagashi festival. But when you sit through that chapter (which is chapter seven, in case you wanted to know), you feel a deeper understanding and meaning brought to the story and I just wish this second game didn't waste so, SO much time reintroducing characters we were already familiar with in the first game and force you to sit through such an agonizing (and somewhat unnecessary) teenage/pre-teen drama.

My eyes! Here! Take them! Grr! Enough is enough! Where's the story that I loved so much from the first game?! It's in chapter seven. So what do I recommend?

Well, if you really want to get to the meat of this particular game, get up to the part where you meet a mysterious (new?) character with green hair. She's dressed rather cutely. After your character has a decent exchange with that (new?) character skip to the end of chapter five. I'm not joking. Just skipping to this point may take you hours (well, maybe not if you have the auto settings on high) and make sure you stop skipping when you see two of something that you thought could not possibly coexist. Then skip to chapter six and don't stop skipping until you see pictures of a shrine and from there start reading to the end. You will meet some familiar faces. Then go to chapter seven and absolutely read all of that. I won't say whether or not to keep reading or skipping from there into the remaining chapters because that is up to you (but I tell you that the story is greatly improved and interesting from chapter seven on and I honestly could not stop reading unless hunger or nature called). 

So perhaps a better strategy would be to just start reading from chapter seven (and don't worry. I'm sure you'll figure out any details you might have missed in the early fluffy chapters). 

In either case, buy this game if you want to know more about the mysterious story behind the cries of the higurashi-- or don't because you can't be bothered with the tremendous amount of drag the beginning chapters offer.

For me, it was really not a good idea to play this game right after the first. I probably should have let my mind simmer. You feel so ready and pumped and the writers basically send you back to kindergarten after all the knowledge you've gained. I really didn't like that. Or maybe I'm just too hard to please. Ha ha!

P.S.
I know I said I didn't condone fast-forwarding in my first review but in this second game I believe it's a must if you don't want to feel a relentless impatience for anything (absolutely ANYTHING) important to happen until chapter seven...just saying.

Wow , what a ride. Like the first chapter, Watanahashi puts you in the role a Maebare Keichi, a normal high school student who moved to the small town of Hinamizawa in the year of 1983.

Life starts in an everyday school life where and you and your friends have fun doing fun activities with your friends. That is until some mysteries about the village you are living in star to unveil and soon enough you are tangled in a mess of a situation.

28337223.review:
If you enjoyed Chapter 1 of Higurashi, you'll likely enjoy Chapter 2. This review is for those who are reluctant to continue after Chapter 1. 

I found the first chapter of Higurashi to be an overall great experience. The suspense and horror parts were written well enough to make them genuinely frightening and engaging, making up for the less interesting expository moments. The horror is still good in Chapter 2, though I found it to be less vivid and inspired than Chapter 1. The first chapter, even in its less believable parts, made an effort to put the player in the main character's perspective and managed to be fairly successful at it. Perhaps because several elements of Chapter 1 are reused, Chapter 2 feels less exciting and engrossing. The end also feels much longer than it needs to be, with several anti-climaxes making the ultimate turn of events less thrilling and more depressing. 

The bigger problem this chapter suffers from is in the exposition. Whereas the build-up in Chapter 1 made the slow introduction worthwhile, Chapter 2 doubles down on the less appealing parts. The club activities are still drawn out and repetitive, and much of the first few hours feels like filler. Furthermore, the treatment of the female characters is abysmal, with even the youngest characters being treated like sex objects at times. It gives the entire first half of the game a very unpleasant atmosphere. While I realize this is an anime game from 2002, I'd really rather not read in detail about a perverted restaurant-goer attempting to get the attractive waiting staff to clean whipped cream off of his crotch. The game as a whole feels more fanservice-y than the first and detracts from the character interactions and plot. 

As mentioned at the start of the review, if you loved Chapter 1, you'll still probably enjoy this chapter, but I found it to be much weaker overall.

It's time for the second round of [i]Higurashi[/i]! *applause, screams*  For those who are squeamish, this chapter in the rural murder mystery can be pretty graphic in descriptions of torture and violence. Now that that delightful tidbit is out of the way, this arc is important for providing us with several keys to the mystery. Some background on Hinamizawa is given, along with details about the worship of Oyashiro-sama. Random fact: in the Shinto religion, the spilling of blood is considered a form of pollution and unclean. Now, this part is creepy enough for Americans, but to the Japanese, this is pretty much blasphemy a la [i]Children of the Corn[/i]. Fun fact over. 

The girl of this route is Mion, the game club leader, and we are introduced to her twin sister, Shion, which provides an answer to the question of [spoiler]how Mion knew Keiichi met with Oishi at the Angel Mort restaurant[/spoiler]. Along the way, we learn about the history of the Sonozaki family's role in Hinamizawa, and get an interesting glimpse at a character we barely got to know in [i]Onikakushi-hen[/i]. It's rather...interesting. Can you figure out what is going on?

So, this arc brings up some interesting questions about just what is going on here. Just wait until we get to the corresponding Answer Arc, [i]Meakashi-hen[/i]. It's a doozy.

25742408.review:
[i]This review: contains no spoilers[/i]

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
	[*][b]Story & atmosphere[/b] --- Unlike Ch. 1, which was about hopelessly fleeing from the unknown wrongs that have been committed, this chapter is more about the realization of past mistakes, the creeping feeling of regret, and the final admission of guilt. Whether this admission is worthy of forgiveness is the main source of suspense.
	[*][b]Mion (character)/character development[/b] --- Ch. 2 does a far better job at balancing setting establishment and character development in regards to its central character, who in this case is Mion. This is partly due to the village's history being integrated into her story rather than being a separate element as was the case with Rena in the previous chapter.
[/list]

[h1]Neutral[/h1]
[list]
	[*][b]Pacing[/b] --- It's expected that the reader is familiar with the characters established in the first chapter, so this one takes less time to set the stage. However, some of the scenes in the first half come across as having been drawn out longer than necessary upon finishing this chapter.
[/list]

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
The reader knows what's coming, so there is less reason to hide the truth. Ch. 2 reels back the psychological horror element from Ch. 1 and becomes more of a slasher. The main character is not alone for this journey. During moments where he would have previously wrestled with his inner doubts on whether he could trust the friend standing beside him, this time he reaches out for help. Seeing it all unfold is only part of the excitement as the highlight of this chapter will come in the last few scenes when everything is thrown into question and the reader must struggle to make sense of what they actually experienced.

Novel length is roughly [b]9 hours[/b] depending on reading speed. It's recommended to [b]buy Higurashi Ch. 2[/b] after and only if you enjoyed Ch. 1.

23786462.review:
Although Watanagashi can be played first or even as a stand-alone novel (much of the information revealed in Onikakushi is presented here as well), this is a comparative review. So, to lay out the pros and cons in relation to Ch1:

Pros (aka. the reason why I do recommend this): 
- The beginning doesn't feel as slow, and it's also a little more entertaining.
- You get to understand some characters' intentions a little better (I'm looking at you, Ooishi).
- The sound during creepy/suspense moments is soooo much better.
- More of the history of Hinamizawa.
- In case you like Mion as much as I do, you get to see plenty of her backstory here as well.

Cons (aka. critique time! May be a little long and spoilery, so be warned):
- It feels like this had a "broader"/more general point of view, focusing on what's going on with everybody and having Keiichi try to find out what happened to other people in these larger-scale incidents, making this more about mystery than psychological horror. Onikakushi, on the other hand, focused on both Rena's and Keiichi's mental breakdowns. The narrative had you at the edge of your seat much more often than Watanagashi. After all, it [i]does[/i] have a bigger impact when you read first-person descriptions of somebody stalking and trying to kill you than when you read a character talking about some other people who died.
- Keiichi's character in this also made the end really lukewarm, in my opinion. His unconditional acceptance and near-blind trust in Mion made the horrible things at the end seem much more distant than his constant paranoia and fear of Rena (his development in both chapters is understandable, however).
- The emphasis on gender roles and stereotypes for the first half of the game is SO ANNOYING.

Also, a little tip: you may think the "after party" is just a little extra, but I do recommend reading it. Characters get together as if they were actors just playing their roles and discuss the story, which may help you mull it over as well. I admit I had found the end to be incredibly underwhelming (especially in comparison to Onikakushi), but the after party shed light on some things I hadn't considered. I guess the generic writing at the start of each chapter really had me underestimating the writers...

23779860.review:
Watanagashi is like a different author writing a slightly altered version of Onikakushi, with the focus of much of the story on Mion instead of Rena. It has the same plodding pace in the first 4 or so chapters, same low budget get's-the-job-done backgrounds, and adds a single character. For the most part this can be "played" on its own, but many of the nuances of the characters, as well as a few references in the opening chapters and music changes (every time the music stops, that creeping dread comes in...). There is much more plot resolution in this chapter than in the previous one, but also raises a lot of questions (it took me about 2 hours to read the final chapter, and it just keeps throwing stuff at you).

Ultimately, I highly recommend this second chapter. It feels to be more informational than mysterious, as with the first chapter, and provides a lot of background information, especially about Mion. If you haven't tried the first chapter, I suggest grabbing that one first as it will make the experience of this chapter more thrilling, but this one can be read right away without becoming lost.

23762763.review:
You’re in a small village, Hinamizawa where an event takes place every year during June; and each event will always have a mysterious death, with someone going missing along with it. No one knows why this is…but it only happens each year after the event. Will you be able to find out who or what lead these tragic events?

[b]Graphics: 7/10[/b]
The graphics are practically the same as the first novel, they have added nothing new here but that’s not to say that it looks any worse. It just looks exactly the same as the first novel. Although, there were a few different locations that were seen in this novel, but apart from that; the way the characters were drawn are the same. 

[b]Storyline: 8/10[/b]
Again, the story starts off very slow and gradually picks up around chapter 10. This time, the main culprit is actually shown and told in a very obvious manner (It’s pretty obvious once you get some ideas within the story). This ruined the mystery for me once I found out who the culprit was as the main character was still ‘not accepting’ the ‘person’, it got a little frustrating. Although, it is a still a great read, but I do prefer the first novel. 

[b]Sound: 6/10[/b]
Apart from a few different soundtracks here and there, it does borrow the same soundtrack heard from the first novel. They did not improve it in any way of form, but they also didn’t change it too drastically that it would mismatch the novel. 

[b]Gameplay: 9/10[/b]
Same deal with the first novel, you get the exact same options. In addition, there were no translation errors that I spotted which is a plus. However, as with the first novel the game crashed a few times, so make to save often to avoid losing progress. 

[b]Price: 10/10[/b]
With a base price of £5.59 it is worth significantly more than the first novel for nearly the same length. That’s not to say that this is not worth reading, this is a really good visual novel that is worth picking up if you want to read the 2nd chapter of the series.

22850234.review:
[h1]Valoración en español:[/h1]

Bueno, no me detendré demasiado en hacer una valoración extensa y detallada porque lo lógico es que ya hayas jugado a la primera parte y ya sepas lo que se ofrece en este juego. Por lo tanto, sólo puntualizaré algunos datos que podrían interesarles a ustedes como posibles futuros compradores.

[list]
[*][b] Esta parte es más cara que la anterior, ¿por qué?:[/b] Lo más probable es que sea porque este capítulo dura mucho más que el anterior. Así que sí, la subida de precio es totalmente comprensible y, desde mi punto de vista tampoco está nada mal para lo que ofrece.

[*][b]Está en inglés/los dibujos son feos/los fondos son fotos y queda cutre/no hay voces y eso me hace plantearme no comprarlo:[/b] Personalmente, [u]a mí me gusta bastante cómo viene el juego de por sí[/u]. Sin embargo, si te preocupa cualquiera de estos asuntos, te interesaría saber que hay muchos mods que la comunidad ha proporcionado que permiten cambiar las imágenes y hasta poner las voces que se han usado en este juego pero en otras plataformas. En cuanto al idioma, que yo sepa no hay todavía ninguna traducción acabada pero sí que leí que había gente trabajando en la del primer capítulo... Así que quizás algún día esté en español también.

[*][b]Ya que es un juego dividido en partes... ¿Tendré que esperar mucho al resto de capítulos?:[/b] Probablemente. Entre la publicación en steam de la primera parte y la publicación de la segunda puede haber pasado alrededor de 6 meses... [strike]O más xD La verdad es que no lo he comprobado.[/strike]

[*][b]A pesar de todo esto y que no se puede interactuar de ninguna manera con la historia... ¿La recomiendas?:[/b] Sí, y mucho. Sobre todo si te gusta el misterio o una trama oscura. La historia, a mi parecer, es muy buena, la música es increíble (en este capítulo aparecen algunas pistas de audio nuevas y son una pasada), los nuevos sprites están bastante bien y el juego de por sí intenta manipular tu percepción... ¡Puede hacerte creer cosas hasta el punto de estar seguro que luego te desmoronará!  No puedo prometerles que les pase eso... Pero es algo que me sucedió en muchas ocasiones a lo largo de toda la saga... Es lo que pasa cuando tomas la postura de un detective (?) Que es de lo que va todo esto.

[*][b]En cualquier caso, ¿no sería más sencillo ver el anime o leer el manga?:[/b] No, no lo creo. Tanto el anime como el manga dejan mucha información fuera y habrá cosas que nunca llegarás a entender del todo. Esto lo sé de primera mano porque es lo que yo hice antes de probar el juego y ahora que lo hago, me doy cuenta de todas las cosas que me perdí o que no entendía. Hay que tener en cuenta que el juego es el recurso original del que se han sacado todas las demás adaptaciones (incluído un live action que apenas tiene sentido), por lo tanto, jugarlo siempre va a ser la mejor opción. Por otro lado, suponiendo que quisieras hacerlo de forma legal (?), te saldría MUCHÍSIMO más caro comprar los tomos del manga que comprar todas las partes del juego. Vamos, yo creo que son todo ventajas.
[/list]
¿Sigues indeciso? Igual puedes echarle un ojo al manga y ver si te podría interesar. Asegúrate también de mirar las valoraciones del primer capítulo, puesto que contienen mucha información valiosa para entender si puede ser la experiencia que buscas.

Si me preguntas a mí, merece la pena.

Hmm. It's not bad but it's nowhere near the spook level of the first chapter, Onikakushi, which builds up to the bad scenes very well. This review's for the second chapter though so let me get to that..

I feel like it's really difficult to read through much of this without having to take a long break before wanting to read it again. Some days it's nice to sit in silence and just read with some background music, but I felt like it was missing voices and the build up to the horrifying secrets of Hinamizawa. It leaves you desiring something more, and it doesn't have the same chilling effect. Highly recommend reading Ch.1 Onikakushi first, regardless.

I would have liked if there was an option for alternative endings or at least SOME sort of thing that allowed you to choose between answers of what to do, as I feel that would have made it a fair bit more interesting as well. It just seems odd having one ending and nothing to play upon.

Also, be sure to download the voice (and graphics, if you so choose) patch if you want the story to be a little more interesting to follow. Since that unfortunately didn't come with the games, I'd probably give this a 7/10. Still an excellent story, and the spooky parts are definitely the most interesting read.

22026032.review:
Honestly, I was extremely nervous about purchasing Onikakushi and Watanagashi. There was a lot of....drama within online communities regarding MG's release. I must say, though, that I was plesantly surprised.

-Being someone who has read all of Higurashi, I can say that, YES, this translation/version does make it 100% possible for you to speculate what is happening.
-The translation is not bad. I had more issues with lines in Watanagashi than I did in Onikakushi, however, overall, MG did a good job.
-Music!! !! ! It only gets better from here on out.
-Honestly? There was a lot of hate being spread around the internet regarding the new sprites. While I do dislike some (which is only natural), I think MOST look great; I am particularly fond of Rena's, Shion's, and Takano's. If you dislike the new sprites, the game contains an option to use the original Sprites (which are hilarious yet endearing in their own way).

I'm not sure at what speed MG intends to release Higurashi, but I hope they do so at a decent speed so we aren't waiting years to finish reading the Steam release. I also hope that other 07th Expansion titles get the same treatment as Higurashi; without spoiling too much, I feel comfortable saying that Higurashi is part of a larger meta world that is explored in other VNs by the same author/artists/musicians. I'll be buying each chapter of Higurashi as it is released.

20611507.review:
As a foreword I have to say that I've seen all anime arcs and OVAs relating to the Higurashi series several years ago, and therefore know how the story and each chapter progresses.

I have to say that I didn't enjoy Watanagashi as much as Onikakushi, which may partially be due to my personal preferences towards the type of horror presented by the first vn. Regardless, it's still an interesting, attention-grabbing and suspenseful story that's highly recommended to anyone who read the first chapter, has seen the anime or is a general horror fan (starting with Onikakushi is pretty much essential due to the way the story is structured)

The story kept my attention throughout and has been practically marathoned as I wasn't able to stop until it was over.
However, it did have a few flaws that impacted its enjoyment.
I found a number of character actions, mainly of the narrating protagonist, to be unrealistic and highly irrational. I understand that emotion and impulse heavily affected his choices and motives, but some of the decisions he makes near the vn's end as well as ways in which he reacts to what's going on seemed highly unbelievable and far from what any human being would do, no matter the situation or their feelings towards others involved. [spoiler]Who in their right mind would show so much sympathy towards a recently revealed mass murderer and follow her into the secluded crime scene alone? Or go outside at night to meet her after she tried to torture them to death? If I was Keiichi, I would feel nothing but disgust and resentment towards Mion. The vague "demon" explanation for her actions didn't feel like enough to change my view of her as a character in this arc, and the concept of heartbreak caused by Rena being given the doll in no way justified her development as a character/sadistic murderer[/spoiler]
Another issue I felt was present in this game, which was more apparent than in the first, was the repetitiveness of music at certain points, especially during longer scenes when the same track would loop many times despite my reasonably fast reading.

Those points asside, I still highly recommend the game and appreciate the good translation as well as vastly improved character art.

20595196.review:
I was surprised when I played this game.  I was expecting either a prequel or a sequel to the first game but this is neither.  Each chapter in the Higurashi series tells the same story, with a number of subtle things changed around to yield different events and outcomes.  Apparently there are four such chapters, with those that come after explaining the mystery behind the previous stories.  So far, it seems like you could play the chapters in either order, but I suspect they will have more impact if you play them in the numbered order and that was probably the intention of the developer.

Given how the series is set up, if you're reading this review and have played the first chapter already, you may be iffy about wanting to go through the same story again.  But although the characters and setting are the same, most of the minor events and major plot points are different, and it gives you more insight into what might be going on in the town.  In fact, it's different enough that it almost feels like someone wrote two different novels with the same premise, setting, and characters.  Only a few things stay the same, and I had no idea what was going to happen until it was all over, even though I had read the first chapter.

If you've played the first chapter, buy this too.  If you haven't and are interested in the Higurashi series, start with the first one.

In terms of the writing, I still think too much time is being spent on the cringe-worthy anime slice of life stuff.  I understand that it is needed to help us get invested in the characters and to contrast with the actual seriousness of the plot, but it is still very badly written.  I watch a lot of anime, and I've never seen slice of life writing that made me cringe as much as the stuff in Higurashi.  But maybe that is because of the story's main character?  His behavior at the end of the story is so unbelievable that it actually broke my immersion.  So maybe the school life stuff seems everything we see is from the point of view of the main character?

Overall, it is a good visual novel and I recommend it highly.  If only the school life portions weren't so childish and ridiculous...

20369165.review:
Remember that Watanagashi isn't so much a computer game as it is a visual novel. In this VN, you're basically reading a novel with pictures, backdrops, music and sound effects thrown in for good measure. I think it makes good use of those elements to help sell the story by setting the mood for the reader, but your results may vary. 

I enjoyed the anime series a while ago, and I continue to enjoy these VNs as they come out. They flesh out the anime's story which came out at a breakneck speed. On this 'replay', I also have to credit the writers on how far ahead they thought about certain story elements while using misdirection. I don't want to spoil the storybecause that's part of the fun of murder mystery stories.

Last time, I wrote down a list of Things I Learned in Hinamizawa. My list was considerably longer, but I narrowed it down to the ten I thought would best fit the events of the game and my impressions.

- Learn to see things from other people's point of view, or risk exploitation when they use this ability against you.
- Keep fighting until the last minute. "As soon as you give up, it's all over."
- It is just as important to talk about your feelings as it is hard to do so. 
- When you are trying to patch things up with someone, don't assume everything is alright just because you are on speaking terms again.
- Ghost stories will never go out of fashion, for better or worse.
- Do not underestimate mankind's capacity for cruelty to what he deems less than himself.
- Lying is much harder than telling the truth. You can't keep the fake facts straight forever
- Someone else might have to pay the price for your mistake, even when you really want to take responsibility for it. 
- You might not like what you find, but you must always persue the truth
- Sometimes a person really is too far gone to help. Your best effort won't go unnoticed by them, but you'll only hurt yourself and others.

19818801.review:
Excellent chapter on Mion

As you can tell from the title art, this chapter focusses on Mion and her sister (I don't think this qualifies as a spoiler since you can easily infer this piece of information from the descriptions of several achievements...). The story feels larger this time. Also we get to know more aspects about the characters and the village Hinamizawa. As a fan of the anime adaptation, I enjoyed this chapter a lot, discovering all the minute but interesting details that were omitted in the anime.

In summary:

Pros:
+The twins theme of Mion/Shion is brilliantly explored. Depending on the context, the writing is funny, entertatining, or horrifying. Also, the twins theme echos well with the duality theme of village Hinamizawa (the bright and dark sides of the village).
+The pacing has been improved. The last chapter has a very slow and sometimes boring start, featuring numerous club activities that have little contribution to the main plot. Not this time. The main story starts rather early on. Also, the story progresses smoothly, compared to the last chapter.
+New background music an better BGM switching.
+Sound effects are utilized better.  
+Rena still rocks!

Cons:
-The reader will be introduced to the curse of Oyashiro-sama in a boring exposition... for the second time ... as if we hadn't got enough in the last chapter.
-The thoughts of the protagonist are written in a really repetitive fashion.
-Although this is chapter dedicated to the character Mion, I cannot find any new portraits for Mion (aside from Shion of course), which is really disappointed.

Overall, I strongly recommend buying it at full price. Looking forward to the next chapter!

As a veteran Higurashi fan, I can assure you that buying the visual novel Higurashi When They Cry: Watanagashi-hen will not be a waste of time, nor money.
For people who have read the visual novels before, Steam's new translation brings yet another layer to the story, establishing rules and themes early on that will be referred to throughout the series.
For people who are coming here from the anime, sitting down to read the original VN is definitely worthwhile, as it includes many backstories, clues, character traits, and messages that I do not believe were properly conveyed in the anime adaptation.
For newcomers who will be reading this for the first time, I can promise you that Higurashi is a well put-together, fully solvable mystery with a lovely message. In fact, I've already seen a few people in the Steam community who are nearing the answer. If you've already read Onikakushi-hen, buying this next installment and continuing to support the new translation is definitely worth your time.

19400465.review:
tl;dr - 10/10. Laughter. Exploration. Warmth. Comraderie. Confusion. Relaxation. Alarm. Obfuscation. Disbelief. Terror. Heartbreak. Finally, [spoiler]?????[/spoiler]. If you are a fan of any mystery/gore/thriller/horror or just visual novels in general, this is a piece of VN history you will regret being a part of.

Edit: After finishing this chapter.

Higuarshi When They Cry: Chapter 2 Watanagashi is an absolutely brilliant kinetic visual novel. You make no choices, simply follow Maebara-kun as he journeys through his new life in Hinamizawa. A quiet town removed from the bustle of the excitement of the city-life. Meeting a wonderful group of friends, you, as the protagonist, will enjoy much laughter as you adjust to your new life, new friends, and new school.

Ever so slowly an impetuous snake begins to slither through your blood while playing. I would strongly recommend playing the first chapter: Onikakushi, however it matters not if you begin here. You begin in the same Hinamizawa, with your same new friends. The club activities are still thrilling and bring you joy.

Can you put a finger on the point that everything went bottom up? Mion Sonozaki, the club leader and your dear friend is acting as if she has a twin for Christ's sake. That's reason enough to cause some suspicion.

Oh...the annual Wataganashi festival is coming! Join your new school friends as you watch the graceful young Rika Furude perform her duties as the Shrine Maiden. Play pranks with Satoko just as you always have. Ooshi-san? That fat detective? Why does he always seem to bother you?

Unlike its predecessor - Wataganashi delves deeper into the history and politics of Hinamizawa. What new tips will you uncover in this Chapter? Is Oyashiro-sama's curse real? Will another be [spoiler]killed and another "demoned away"?[/spoiler] Or will the events unfold differently through the chattering of the higurashi?

If this is on sale: don't give it a second thought before purchasing.
If this is full price: I *strongly* suggest purchasing it. The playtime is *well* worth they price.
Play Chapter 1 first if you can. If you can't, just play this beautifully twisted game.
If you are a fan of this series: Please support 07th Expansion so that they may release more games on steam.

19219034.review:
I know my time on this game is bloated...no, I'm not a slow reader, I just left it on.

Higurashi Chapter 2: Watanagashi
Where to even start with this masterpiece? If you loved Onikakushi (I know I did), then you're sure to love this one as well. If you haven't read through Onikakushi, go pick it up for a few dollars. Trust me, it's money well spent. Watanagashi gets into the mystery a little faster than Onikakushi did, since it doesn't have to establish characters as much as the first chapter did. However, there is a new character in this one, so still expect plenty of set-up before the madness begins. Also, the story this time around is a bit less mysterious. Onikakushi ended on a really weird note (trust me, this one does too), but having the knowledge from the first chapter really seems to make puzzle pieces fit a bit better. Overall, though, still plenty of mystery to go over, and you get a MUCH more detailed look into the past of Hinamiza. Trust me, it isn't pretty.

The only negatives I can give this game are a few typos here and there, but with work this dense, that's always going to happen. It's not something a patch can't fix either!

Oh, and in case you are new to this series and are on this page, Higurashi has no interaction when it comes to gameplay. I see so many people getting upset that it doesn't have branches, but honestly, there's so much mystery here that you're sure to play it through more than once! I know I am! Trust me, it's still worth it even without the choices.

10/10 
Just fantastic. Now pardon me while I go buy the manga chapters...

19125611.review:
Watanagashi was a complete and utter mind f**k. There were many moments where I was absolutely stunned and could do nothing but sit in disbelief with my mouth agape.

Higurashi when they cry - Watanagashi Is the second chapter in the Higurashi series. The basic premise is that: protagonist Keiichi Maebara recently moved to a small village named Hinamizawa in the countryside. The story starts about a month after he moved to the village and he had just gotten settled in.
Since this is the 2nd chapter, less time is spent introducing the reader to the world and characters.
The mood start off happy and light hearted to get the reader invested in the characters, then gradually become sinister.

[olist]
[*] [b]Story & Characters:[/b] Though the story is faster paced compared to Onikakushi, it still unfolds quite slow. It wasn't so slow to bore me. In fact, I think it's better for it. Because the story develops slowly and has a lot of Slice of Life moments during the opening chapters, It forces you to become closely attached to the characters. This make the later half of the story all the more brutal. Because the characters are so relatable. Their interactions were enjoyable to read about, and often hilarious. I got so invested in the characters that bad things happening to the characters were pretty upsetting.

The writing is great. Almost everything written about has a deeper meaning, if you were to re-read the story, you would see lots of clues hiding in plain sight. This is the kind of story where you aren't given a concise answer to the mystery, and the reader is supposed to look at the clues and come up with their own theory as to what the answer to the mystery is. (However, there is a "correct" answer). There are also many red herrings, so you are sometimes getting thrown off.

[b]Story: 9/10[/b]

[*] [b]Art & Graphics:[/b] The art style of the sprites looks good. The characters all have interesting designs. However my complaint is that often, the sprite doesn't match the descriptions of the characters facial expressions. [url=http://i.imgur.com/wIDaY8Y.png]This[/url] Is apparently Rena with an intense stare XD. This is common with most of the characters. However it isn't a huge deal.
Another complaint, is the background images are just photographs put through a filter to appear more... cartoonish/cell shaded? Anyway, when Onikakushi released on steam, it didn't take a month before someone released a mod which used the PS3 Sprites and Backgrounds. They will likely release a similar mod for Watanagashi.

One of the major issues, is the way the text is displayed. In most visual novels, the text appears in a text box at the bottom of the screen, and is usually titled with the speakers name. However, in Higurashi, The text takes up large portions of the screen, often covers the sprites and doesn't show the speakers name. Sometimes you don't know who is saying what. It becomes less of a problem later on. Because each character has a unique ways of speaking. But still, it can be really confusing. I hope to see a UI mod in the future.

[b]Art: 7/10[/b]

[*] [b]Music & Sound:[/b] The music is well made. The music does it's job, and can be atmospheric. During some of the creepy moments, you almost don't notice the music. The visual novel is so immersive, it all blends together. The music is pretty catchy, and I never found the music to get boring. Most of the tracks loop seamlessly.
The sound effects are used really well. They added a lot to the atmosphere along with the music. On more than one occasion I even jumped. I also was legitimately creeped out and glanced behind me a couple of times. It's great to read after midnight.

[b]Music & Sound: 7.5[/b][/olist]

Overall, this chapter is slightly better than the last. The last chapter had more Slice of Life content, and this one had more disturbing, s**t hitting the fan moments. As stated earlier, the pacing is faster. So if the pacing of the first one bored you, this one should be a more interesting read. Though, it still takes quite a while to get started. So if you are an impatient reader, and don't want to invest a few hours into a story before it kicks into full gear, then this visual novel may not be for you. Most people agree that the Higurashi Visual Novels are better than the anime (I share this opinion). However, if you are the impatient type, I would recommend buying the anime instead. As the Anime is still quite good. You can usually get the DVD from Ebay, or Amazon at a fair price. 

[b]Visual Novel Length: 15-20 hours[/b]

[b]Overall: 8/10[/b] Would write a review longer than that which I am reviewing again XD.

19125116.review:
Do I recommend it? DO I RECOMMEND?! 1000% yes I do. Even at the slight price jump, this chapter is worth it. 

This VN was an emotional roller coaster for me. The writing got better here then in Onikakushi. The story starts out as a fun humorous experience in the vein of Gintama I'd say with some of the ridiculousness. It then subtly lays the ground the plot ahead, but while it does this, at the midway point it kind of drags. After this midway point, you move onto the mystery part of the story. After this I cried. A lot. I've seen the anime and know the series plot already and all its secrets so maybe it made me cry because I knew what was to come. But the writing for the emotions of Keichi could not be captured like how an anime could try. His personal struggle with each event was heart wrenching. While it was limited to a single perspective unlike the anime (which showed more of the truth), it did a better job of conveying a story and the emotion behind it. The reused bgms still feel a little out of place and cheap imo, but the new ones that play late in the VN fit the mood perfectly and make it all the more emotional. This VN is simply wonderful and probably the best to come onto Steam.

11/10 - Would cry like a little pussy again

19115832.review:
[i]Watanagashi[/i], the second chapter of the episodic Higurashi series, has finally crept onto Steam. As expected from the stellar work done on CH1, MangaGamer have not disappointed in making [i]Watanagashi[/i] a worthwhile purchase:

[list]
[*] Unlike the previous (non-Steam) MG localization of Higurashi, no licensing issues hinder this release. The original music is fully intact as it was in the original release nearly 13 years ago.
[*] Like CH1, the translation quality of this release far surpasses the 2009 MG localization or the various fanslation projects, owing to MangaGamer's decision to retranslate this behemoth from scratch. Wordplay, idioms, descriptions, characterizations, all are delicately handled in a way that immerses the reader without straying from the original transcript; in many situations, comparing this new translation to the old is like night and day.
[*] Detailed new character art has been provided for the user's convenience, replacing the original low-res Ryukishi art if so desired. Alternatively, those who prefer the original art have the option to switch between the two on the fly by pressing 'P'. Going even further beyond these options, MangaGamer's intentional decision to allow modding of Higurashi's graphic assets means that discerning fans can even go as far as using the PS2 character sprites, or the PS3 backgrounds, or even custom fanmade sprites. Even voice mods using the VO of the older console releases of Higurashi are popping up, thanks to the flexibility provided by this rerelease's engine.
[/list]

I can only assume if you're reading this review for CH2 you were (rightfully) in love with CH1 and wanted to see if MangaGamer's handling of CH2 is up to snuff. The answer is a resounding 'yes', and you should go out of your way to support such an excellent release.

19111193.review:
An excellent story and worthwhile release. This is one of the best arcs in the series.

If you don't know what to expect: keep an open mind. The story may or may not be what it seems at points. There are also slice-of-life and romance elements, particularly with this chapter.

There are some minor typos in the translation, mostly involving missing spaces after punctuation. Aside from that, I'm very pleased with this one.

19068822.review:
"Higurashi When They Cry - Watanagashi" หรือถ้าให้แปลเป็นไทยก็คือ "ยามเมื่อเหล่าจักจั่นกรีดร้อง - บทเทศกาลมรณะ" (จริง ๆ ชื่อของบทจะแปลว่า "เทศกาลลอยนุ่น" แต่อันนี้ผมใช้ชื่ออย่างเป็นทางการตามมังงะฉบับภาษาไทยแบบลิขสิทธิ์) เป็น Visual Novel แนวเขย่าขวัญ (โอเค ภาพประกอบอาจแลดูเหมือนไม่เป็นเช่นนั้น แต่ผมเตือนคุณแล้วนะ) แบบอ่านอย่างเดียวและเป็นตอนต่อของ "Higurashi When They Cry - Onikakuchi" (ยามเมื่อเหล่าจักจั่นกรีดร้อง - บทปิศาจลักพา) ดังนั้นไม่ว่าคุณจะมีเหตุผลที่ดีเพียงใดก็ตาม ถ้าคุณยังไม่ได้มีโอกาสอ่านบทแรกให้จบ ผมก็ขอแนะนำให้คุณอ่านให้จบก่อนที่จะเริ่มต้นใหม่กับบทนี้ โดยเหตุผลสำคัญนั้นก็เป็นเพราะเนื้อหานั้นจะไม่มีการเกริ่นถึงรายละเอียดโดยภาพรวมของฮินามิซาวะอันเป็นฉากหลังของเรื่อง รายละเอียดโดยรวมของตัวละคร หรือรายละเอียดปลีกย่อยใด ๆ ก็ตามอีก ซึ่งนั่นอาจจะทำให้ผู้เล่นใหม่ที่ไม่ได้อ่านบทแรกมาก่อนสับสนได้นั่นเองครับ

ถึงแม้จะเป็น "ตอนต่อ" กระนั้น "บทเทศกาลมรณะ" ก็ไม่ได้เชื่อมโยงใด ๆ กันกับ "บทปิศาจลักพา" หรือถ้าจะให้สรุปให้เห็นภาพง่าย ๆ เนื้อหาที่เกิดขึ้นในบทเทศกาลมรณะนั้นก็คือเหตุการณ์ที่เกิดขึ้นคนละ Timelines หรือคนละ Route แล้วแต่จะเรียก (ซึ่งถ้าคุณเคยได้ชมอนิเมะหรืออ่านมังงะมาก่อน คุณก็คงจะรู้ว่ามันไม่ถูกเสียทีเดียว แต่ที่ผมเลือกใช้คำอธิบายเช่นนี้ก็เพื่อป้องกันการ Spoil แบบเต็มดอกส่วนหนึ่ง) โดยในบทนี้สิ่งที่ตัวเอกของเรานั้นจะต้องเผชิญนั้นไม่ใช่ความหวาดหวั่นอันเกิดจาก "เสียงฝีเท้าที่เกินมาหนึ่งก้าว" อีกต่อไป แต่สิ่งที่เขาจะต้องเผชิญนั้นกลับกลายเป็น "ปิศาจ" ที่ตัวเขาเองนั้นเคยได้รู้จักเป็นอย่างดี เคอิจิจำเป็นที่จะต้องทำทุกอย่างเพื่อไขปริศนาการหายตัวไปของคนรู้จักและเพื่อนพ้องของเขาให้ได้ก่อนที่ภัยร้ายจะรุกมาจนถึงตัวเขาเองในที่สุด

"บทเทศกาลมรณะ" เป็นบทที่โดยส่วนตัวผมเองนั้นชอบที่สุดด้วยเหตุผลหลาย ๆ ประการ (ซึ่งผมไม่ขอปฏิเสธว่าเหตุผลหลักเป็นเพราะผมชอบตัวละครอย่างมิองเป็นการส่วนตัว :P ) และถ้าคุณชอบบทปิศาจลักพา คุณก็ต้องชอบบทเทศกาลมรณะนี้เช่นกันครับ

คะแนน:
ขอไม่ระบุเป็นตัวเลข แต่นี่คือหนึ่งใน VN ที่ผมแนะนำว่า "ไม่ควรพลาด"

ข้อดี:
+ เนื้อหาที่เริ่มต้นได้อย่างเช้าที่สดใส แต่จบลงได้ราวเย็นวันพายุเข้า
+ ตัวละครถูกออกแบบขึ้นใหม่ทั้งหมด (ซึ่งดูดีขึ้นอย่างมากเมื่อเทียบกับต้นฉบับ)
+ เป็นบทที่มีปริศนาเข้าท่าและสมเหตุสมผลที่สุด (อย่างน้อยก็ในมุมมองของผม)

ข้อเสีย:
- คุณอาจจำเป็นที่จะต้องรอ Mod จาก PS3 เหมือนกันกับบทที่หนึ่งเพื่อให้ได้อรรถรสในการเล่นอย่างเต็มที่ (ณ ตอนนี้บทที่หนึ่งมีคนใจดี Mod ให้แก่คุณแล้ว พบได้ในส่วน Guide ของ Community Hub)

Well, I must admit that I rarely post replies here since I'm quite a lazy person. Most of the time, I just lurk and when I dare to post anything, it's usually only a handful of words.

Today I made an exception, and here's why...

If you've browsed the board lately, you've most likely noticed the colossal amount of threads about a game called Kingdom Come: Deliverance.

Personally, I've first heard about this game when I launched Steam yesterday and saw a big "now available" pop-up. I was quite intrigued about this game--since the screenshots looked so realistic--that I decided to see how popular it was...

Well, when I looked at the Steam statistics yesterday at around 1pm, Kingdom Come: Deliverance was the 4th MOST PLAYED game on STEAM... just under Dota 2! The two other games above were the usual PUBG and CSGO.

Needless to say, this made me INSTANTLY hit the "purchase this game" button, and to be honest, this was the best decision I made in my entire life... after I quit smoking! 

When I say that this game makes all the other games obsolete, it's because it REALLY does. Nothing comes close to Kingdom Come: Deliverance, and I've had my fair share of video games.

I was so mesmerized by the quality of this game, that I didn't even leave a review on Steam...

Instead, I took a pen and I wrote a REAL letter to thank the marvelous team in Czech Republic, because it would have been a grotesque insult to leave a banal online review for this unique piece of art!

Anyways, the reason I made this post is simply because Kingdom Come: Deliverance is the ONLY game that managed to REVIVE my interest in video games. An interest that was slowly dying, like a mellow camp fire under the frigid Alaskan rain in April.

So, if this game had the power to make a lazy high school dropout write such a long post about it, you can be 100% sure that you'll enjoy every second of it.
